title: 110_hr746
content: The "Safe and Orderly Withdrawal From Iraq Act" includes provisions for the withdrawal of US Armed Forces and defense contractors from Iraq, transfer of military facilities, prohibition on further deployment of forces, assistance to Iraqi Security Forces, social and economic reconstruction activities, asylum for Iraqi citizens, and a definition section. The Secretary of Defense must begin withdrawing troops and contractors from Iraq within 30 days of the Act's enactment, completing the process within 180 days. No increase in troop levels is allowed during this period. The Act prohibits any increase in troop levels in Iraq without prior authorization from Congress. Troops withdrawn from Iraq can be redeployed to locations outside of Iraq, including adjacent countries or Afghanistan. Exceptions include retaining troops for embassy security and reconstruction activities. The Secretary of Defense may retain personnel in Iraq for reconstruction projects at the request of the Government of Iraq. Funds can be used for the safe withdrawal of Armed Forces and defense contractors from Iraq. The President must transfer US military facilities in Iraq to the Iraqi government. Funds cannot be used to deploy US Armed Forces to Iraq after withdrawal. Assistance will be provided to Iraqi security forces and multinational forces in Iraq. SEC. 5. Assistance to Iraqi security forces and multinational forces in Iraq allows funds for financial assistance or equipment. SEC. 6. Continuation of social and economic reconstruction activities in Iraq permits funds for reconstruction activities. SEC. 7. Asylum or other means of protection for Iraqi citizens is also addressed. SEC. 7 of the Act allows the President to arrange asylum or protection for Iraqi citizens endangered by the withdrawal of Armed Forces from Iraq. The term "Armed Forces" is defined in SEC. 8 of the Act.
